title: Bitcoin Genesis Block
summary: The Bitcoin Genesis Block, also known as Block 0, is the first block in the Bitcoin blockchain, mined by Satoshi Nakamoto on January 3, 2009. It contained an embedded message, The Times 03-Jan-2009 Chancellor on brink of second bailout for bank.

title: Bitcoin Pizza Day
summary: Laszlo Hanyecz pays 10,000 BTC for two Papa John's pizzas, marking the first and most famous real-world Bitcoin transaction.

title: Silk Road Launches
summary: Ross Ulbricht launches Silk Road, the first major darknet marketplace using Bitcoin for anonymous payments. From February 6, 2011 to July 23, 2013 there were approximately 1,229,465 transactions completed on the site. The total revenue generated from these sales was 9,519,664 Bitcoins, and the total commissions collected by Silk Road from the sales amounted to 614,305 Bitcoins.

title: The First Mt. GOX Hack
summary: On June 19th, 2011, a security breach of the Mt. Gox bitcoin exchange caused the nominal price of a bitcoin to fraudulently drop to one cent on the Mt. Gox exchange, after a hacker allegedly used credentials from a Mt. Gox auditor's compromised computer illegally to fabricate a large number of bitcoins for himself.

crimeline.aftermath: Exchange briefly suspended trading and eventually restored prices.

title: First Bitcoin Halving
summary: Bitcoin's block reward halves from 50 BTC to 25 BTC at block 210,000, the first of its kind.

title: Mt. Gox Collapses
summary: On February 7th, 2014, Mt. Gox halted all bitcoin withdrawals. The company said it was pausing withdrawal requests `to obtain a clear technical view of the currency processes`. On 24 February 2014, Mt. Gox suspended all trading, and hours later its website went offline, returning a blank page. Around 850,000 BTC (~$450M at the time) were stolen over several years. On 14 March 2019, the Tokyo District Court found KarpelÃ¨s guilty of falsifying data to inflate Mt. Gox's holdings by $33.5 million, for which he was sentenced to 30 months in prison, suspended for four years, meaning he will serve no time unless he commits additional offenses over the next four years.

crimeline.aftermath: Exchange filed for bankruptcy; creditors still awaiting payouts a decade later.

title: Ethereum Mainnet Launch
summary: Ethereum goes live with the Frontier release, introducing smart contracts and a Turing-complete blockchain.

title: ok can you guys stop trading
summary: An attacker exploits a reentrancy bug in The DAO smart contract, draining 3.6M ETH (~$60M), leading to the controversial Ethereum hard fork. When the DAO was being drained by an attacker (millions of ETH were being siphoned off due to a vulnerability), Vitalik and other Ethereum community members urged exchanges to pause trading, deposits, and withdrawals to prevent the stolen ETH from being quickly liquidated and causing further damage to the market.

crimeline.aftermath: Ethereum community split; hard fork created ETH and ETC chains.

title: Second Bitcoin Halving
summary: Bitcoin's block reward halves from 25 BTC to 12.5 BTC at block 420,000.

title: Bitfinex Is Hacked by `Razzlekhan`
summary: Hackers steal 119,756 BTC (~$72M) from Bitfinex exchange in the second largest Bitcoin theft at the time. In 2022, U.S. authorities arrested Ilya Lichtenstein and Heather `Razzlekhan` Morgan for laundering the stolen funds, marking one of the largest financial seizure cases ever. In 2026, Ilya Lichtenstein, was released early from prison under the First Step Act and is now on home confinement.

crimeline.aftermath: Bitfinex issued BFX tokens to affected users; DOJ later recovered some funds in 2022.

title: ICO Boom Begins
summary: Initial Coin Offerings explode in popularity, raising billions for blockchain projects with minimal regulation.

title: China Bans ICOs
summary: China's central bank declares all ICO fundraising illegal, triggering a market crash and setting a precedent for regulatory crackdowns.

title: Bitcoin Reaches $20,000
summary: Bitcoin hits its first major all-time high of nearly $20,000, capturing mainstream attention and sparking institutional interest.

title: Cryptopia Exchange Hack
summary: Cryptopia announced a major security breach, reporting “significant losses” and suspending trading as hackers siphoned crypto from its wallets. The breach occurred after days of unexplained “unscheduled maintenance,” and large movements of ETH and other tokens were publicly spotted onchain before the official acknowledgment.

crimeline.aftermath: Exchange went into liquidation; partial funds recovered for creditors.

title: Third Bitcoin Halving
summary: Bitcoin's block reward halves from 12.5 BTC to 6.25 BTC at block 630,000.

title: Uniswap V2 Launches
summary: Uniswap V2 launches with ERC20-ERC20 pools, flash swaps, and price oracles, becoming the leading decentralized exchange.

title: Defi Summer 2020 Begins
summary: Almost $90 billion worth of trading volume happened across decentralized exchanges on Ethereum over 2020. The majority of the volume and growth happened over the last 4-5 months during DeFi summer.

title: KuCoin Exchange Hack
summary: KuCoin suffered a massive security breach in which hackers accessed private keys for the exchange’s hot wallets and stole an estimated ~$280 million+ in crypto assets including BTC, ETH, XRP, LTC, and many ERC-20 tokens — one of the largest exchange hacks in history.

crimeline.aftermath: Most funds recovered through project freezes and law enforcement; exchange compensated users.

title: Poly Network Hack
summary: A hacker exploits Poly Network cross-chain protocol, stealing over $600M in the largest DeFi hack at the time. The hacker later returned most funds.

crimeline.aftermath: Hacker returned funds after negotiations; was offered security role.

title: Cream Finance Flash Loan Attack
summary: Cream Finance suffers its third hack of 2021, losing $130M in a sophisticated flash loan oracle manipulation attack.

crimeline.aftermath: Third major exploit for Cream; protocol credibility severely damaged.

title: Bitcoin Hits $69,000 ATH
summary: Bitcoin reaches all-time high of $69k, marking the peak of the 2021 bull run before a prolonged bear market.

title: Wormhole Bridge Hack
summary: Wormhole cross-chain bridge is exploited for 120,000 wETH (~$320M) due to a signature verification vulnerability.

crimeline.aftermath: Jump Crypto rescued them and replaced the stolen funds to make users whole.

title: There has been a security breach on the Ronin Network
summary: North Korean hackers (Lazarus Group) exploit the Ronin bridge used by Axie Infinity, stealing $625M and losing roughly 173,600 ETH and 25.5 million USDC.

crimeline.aftermath: FBI attributed attack to Lazarus Group; Sky Mavis raised funds to reimburse users.

title: Terra/LUNA Collapse
summary: The Terra blockchain’s algorithmic stablecoin TerraUSD (UST) lost its $1-USD peg, triggering a rapid devaluation that saw UST fall to pennies and its sister token LUNA collapse from over ~$100 to near zero within days. This “death spiral” wiped out around $45 billion in market capitalization and severely shook confidence across the broader crypto market. The design relied on an unstable mint-and-burn arbitrage mechanism rather than traditional collateral, making it especially fragile once large holders began selling. The collapse led to bankruptcies, investor losses worldwide, and intense scrutiny by regulators; Terraform Labs ultimately filed for bankruptcy and founder Do Kwon has since been convicted and sentenced to 15 years in prison for fraud tied to the crash.

crimeline.aftermath: Do Kwon charged with fraud; triggered cascading failures across crypto lending platforms.

title: Celsius Network Freezes Withdrawals
summary: Crypto lender Celsius halts all withdrawals citing 'extreme market conditions,' later filing for bankruptcy with $4.7B hole.

crimeline.aftermath: Filed for bankruptcy; CEO Alex Mashinsky later arrested for fraud.

title: Three Arrows Capital Defaults
summary: Three Arrows Capital (3AC) was a Singapore-based cryptocurrency hedge fund founded by Kyle Davies and Su Zhu that collapsed in June 2022 after failing to meet large margin calls amid the broader crypto market downturn — particularly losses tied to Terra/LUNA and other leveraged positions. A court in the British Virgin Islands ordered the firm into liquidation on June 27, 2022, and it subsequently filed for Chapter 15 bankruptcy in the U.S., owing around $3.5 billion to creditors including major lenders like Genesis and Voyager.

crimeline.aftermath: Founders fled Singapore; creditors pursuing billions in claims.

title: Voyager Digital Bankruptcy
summary: Crypto broker Voyager files for bankruptcy after Three Arrows Capital default, leaving customers unable to access $1.3B in assets.

crimeline.aftermath: Bankruptcy proceedings; FTX initially bid to acquire before its own collapse.

title: Nomad Bridge Hack
summary: Nomad was a cross-chain bridge protocol that allowed users to transfer assets between blockchains like Ethereum, Moonbeam, Avalanche, and others. A routine smart contract upgrade in June 2022 introduced a critical bug in the Replica contract: it incorrectly marked a zero hash (0x00) as a trusted root. This flaw let anyone process arbitrary messages without proper verification, essentially turning the bridge into an open vault. $190m was drained in a chaotic 'free-for-all' attack where hundreds of users exploited the vulnerability.

crimeline.aftermath: First 'crowd-sourced' hack; some whitehats returned funds.

title: Ethereum Merge
summary: Ethereum successfully transitions from Proof of Work to Proof of Stake, reducing energy consumption by ~99.95%.

title: The Collapse of FTX
summary: FTX, the third-largest crypto exchange, files for bankruptcy after revelations of misusing $8B+ in customer funds through Alameda Research.

crimeline.aftermath: SBF arrested and convicted of fraud; sentenced to 25 years in prison.

title: Genesis Trading Bankruptcy
summary: Genesis Global Capital files for bankruptcy owing $3.5B to creditors after being hit by Three Arrows Capital and FTX collapses.

crimeline.aftermath: DCG parent company faced SEC charges; settlement reached with NY AG.

title: Euler Finance Flash Loan Attack
summary: Euler Finance lending protocol is exploited for $197M in a flash loan attack targeting the donation and liquidation mechanics.

crimeline.aftermath: Attacker negotiated return of funds after on-chain messages and negotiations.

title: SEC vs Ripple Partial Victory
summary: Judge rules XRP is not a security when sold on exchanges, marking a significant legal precedent for the crypto industry.

title: Mixin Network Hack
summary: Mixin Network cloud service provider is hacked, resulting in approximately $200M in losses from the decentralized network. Founder Feng Xiaodong stated that only about half of user assets could be guaranteed safe initially, with a plan to compensate the rest over time. The company also publicly offered the hacker a $20 million `bug bounty` reward for returning the funds.

crimeline.aftermath: Network suspended deposits/withdrawals; offered 10% bug bounty to attacker.

title: SEC Twitter Hacked for Fake Bitcoin ETF Approval
summary: The SEC's official X account was compromised via SIM swap attack. A hacker posted a fake announcement claiming the SEC had approved spot Bitcoin ETFs for listing on national securities exchanges. The post even included a fabricated quote attributed to SEC Chair Gary Gensler, causing Bitcoin's price to spike briefly from around $45,000 to nearly $48,000 in minutes Eric Council Jr. was later arrested for the hack.

crimeline.aftermath: FBI arrested Eric Council Jr. in October 2024. Real ETF approval came the next day.

title: Bitcoin Spot ETF Approved
summary: SEC approves 11 spot Bitcoin ETFs including BlackRock and Fidelity, marking a historic milestone for institutional crypto adoption.

title: Ansem Tweets About $WIF On Sphere
summary: A joke tweet about putting Dogwifhat (WIF) on the Las Vegas Sphere rapidly escalated into a community-funded campaign. Within hours, a fundraiser site was launched, and by March 13, 2024, Ansem announced the campaign was fully funded. Despite the successful fundraising, there has been no $WIF on Sphere.

title: $SLERF Developer Accidentally Burns $10M
summary: Slerf developer accidentally burned all $10M of presale investor funds while trying to distribute tokens. Instead of killing the project, the community rallied and pushed market cap to $660M, turning a disaster into a bizarre success story.

crimeline.aftermath: Community rallied, token reached $660M market cap. Became legendary meme moment.

title: 12-Year-Old Rug Pulls $QUANT for $20K
summary: A 12-year-old kid rug pulled $QUANT token for $20,000 during a live stream. Crypto Twitter responded by pumping the market cap to $85M to 'teach the kid a lesson' about the power of community. The crypto community doxxed him, revealing his identity, but he continued by launching another coin, `Sorry`, only to rug it, too.

root_cause: Exit scam by minor during livestream
crimeline.aftermath: Crypto Twitter pumped token to $85M market cap in retaliation. Became viral story.

title: Fourth Bitcoin Halving
summary: Bitcoin's block reward halves from 6.25 BTC to 3.125 BTC at block 840,000, continuing the predictable monetary policy.

title: Sahil Orchestrates Mass Celebrity Token Scams
summary: Sahil rose to notoriety in 2024 by orchestrating numerous celebrity-linked memecoin launches on Solana, convincing stars like Caitlyn Jenner, Jason Derulo, Iggy Azalea, and others to promote tokens before allegedly dumping holdings for massive profits—estimated at $2-6.5 million initially, with claims of up to $30 million across over 100 schemes.

crimeline.aftermath: Exposed celebrity token scam operations. Multiple tokens crashed.

title: Church of the Chicken
summary: Pastor Kelby of the viral 'Church of the Chicken' used his influence to promote low-cap memecoins for payment, leading to his expulsion from the church he founded.It started as an absurd meme coin called Smoking Chicken Fish (SCF) on the Solana blockchain. The community turned it into a mock religion, complete with `chickenmandments` (humorous rules), daily `sermons` (often reading self-help books), and even plans to build a real physical church in Marfa, Texas. They registered as a nonprofit and raised donations (including over $130k from `whales` for property).

root_cause: Influencer using religious authority for financial gain
crimeline.aftermath: Pastor expelled from church, church plans collapsed.

title: Gainzy Falsely Named as UHC CEO Killer
summary: A viral post falsely accused crypto 'trader' Gainzy as the UnitedHealthcare CEO killer, sparking outrage and investigation from Crypto Twitter.

title: Radiant Capital Multi-Chain Hack
summary: Radiant Capital suffers a $50M exploit across Arbitrum and BNB Chain through compromised multi-sig signers. Attacker's trojaned the computers of multiple team members. Team members saw and verified good multisig data on screens, but their hardware wallets signed bad data.

crimeline.aftermath: Protocol paused lending markets; investigation ongoing.

title: Chill Guy Creator Opposes Memecoin
summary: The creator of the 'Chill Guy' art publicly opposed its use in crypto and threatened legal action. The Chill Guy memecoin reached $488 million market cap at its peak.

title: $HAWK Token Crashes After Launch
summary:
• The $HAWK token launched on December 4, 2024, heavily hyped by Welch and her team. Within minutes to hours, it surged to a peak market cap of roughly $490–500 million due to intense retail FOMO.
• Almost immediately after peaking, the token collapsed by approximately 90–95%, with some reports placing the crash within 20–30 minutes.
• The crash wiped out billions of dollars in paper value, leaving most holders with massive losses.
• On-chain analysis (including Bubblemaps) revealed extreme supply concentration red flags.
• Roughly 96–97% of the token supply was controlled by a small cluster of insider wallets (team, pre-sale investors, KOLs).
• Only an estimated 3–4% of the total supply was genuinely available to the public at launch.

crimeline.aftermath: Class action lawsuite was filed. Became yet another cautionary tale about celebrity tokens.

title: Bitcoin Breaks $100,000
summary: Bitcoin surpasses $100,000 for the first time, likely driven by ETF inflows and post-halving dynamics.

title: Scooter Exposes Rizzmas as Complete Scam
summary: Crypto influencer Scooter revealed Rizzmas was a complete scam.

root_cause: Coordinated scam targeting social media users
crimeline.aftermath: Market cap crashed from $100M to $20M after exposure. Whistleblower faced harassment.

title: $TRUMP Launch Sparks Frenzy, Then Massive Drawdown
summary: Donald Trump officially promotes the ($TRUMP) token, triggering a rapid speculative surge in January. Followed by a 90%+ drawdown by the end of the year.

title: $MELANIA Token Launches Immediately After $TRUMP
summary: The $MELANIA token had a peak market cap of aroun $150m, followed by a 98% drawdown over the year.

title: Milei and Hayden Team Up To Rug Pull
summary: On February 14, 2025, Milei posted on Twitter endorsing $LIBRA as a project to fund small Argentine businesses and boost the economy, using his slogan `long live freedom`. The token's market cap surged dramatically to around $4-4.6 billion within hours as retail investors FOMO'd in. However, the price crashed almost immediately (dropping over 90-95% to near zero), resulting in massive investor losses estimated at $250-251 million. Multiple wallets linked to the project's insiders withdrew roughly $99-107 million (sometimes reported as high as $110 million) from the liquidity pool shortly after the hype peaked.

crimeline.aftermath: As of late 2025/early 2026, investigations continue, with reports of suspicious transfers and frozen funds. Hayden walks free.

title: Bybit Exchange Suffers Record $1.5B Ethereum Heist
summary: Dubai-based centralized exchange Bybit was hacked during a routine transfer between cold and warm wallets. Hackers, widely attributed to North Korea's state-sponsored Lazarus Group, stole approximately $1.4–1.5 billion worth of Ethereum (ETH), specifically around 401,000 ETH.

root_cause: Compromised developer infrastructure at Safe{Wallet} (multi-sig provider)
crimeline.aftermath: Bybit quickly reassured users that client funds were safe.

title: Mantra (OM) Token Dumps ~90% in Hours
summary: Mantra (OM) experienced a dramatic 90% price crash within an hour, dropping from over $6 to below $1, with liquidations exceeding $70 million. CEO JP Mullin attributed the crash to 'reckless forced closures' initiated by centralized exchanges on OM account holders without sufficient warning.

crimeline.aftermath: Unknown

title: Coinbase Customer Data Breach via Rogue Support Agents
summary: Coinbase disclosed a major customer data breach in which cybercriminals bribed and recruited a group of rogue overseas customer support agents to steal Coinbase customer information from internal support systems. The stolen information included names, contact details, partial Social Security numbers, masked bank info, government ID images, and account history — but no passwords, private keys, or direct access to funds. Coinbase received a $20 million ransom demand from the attackers, which it refused; instead it offered a $20 million reward for information leading to the attackers’ arrest and vowed to reimburse affected customers.

root_cause: Bribery and recruitment of Coinbase support personnel
Insufficient internal access controls over sensitive user data
crimeline.aftermath: Coinbase refused the $20M ransom demand. Instead offers $20m for information leading to arrests.

title: Cetus Protocol Smart Contract Exploit Drains $223M
summary: Cetus Protocol, a major decentralized exchange and liquidity provider on the Sui blockchain, was exploited for roughly $220 – $260 million. The attacker took advantage of a vulnerability in the protocol’s smart contract/overflow handling logic, allowing them to manipulate liquidity and drain multiple pools in under 15 minutes.

root_cause: Price manipulation via spoof token insertion
Smart contract vulnerability in AMM pricing feeds
crimeline.aftermath: Cetus plans to make users whole.

title: Circle (CRCL) IPOs
summary: Circle, issuer of USDC, begins trading $31/share and at a valuation of $8 billion.

title: Nobitex Centralized Exchange Hack Drains ~$90M
summary: Nobitex, Iran’s largest cryptocurrency exchange, was hit by a major cyberattack in which attackers drained tens of millions of dollars (roughly $80–$90 M+) from its hot wallets. The group calling itself Gonjeshke Darande (also known as “Predatory Sparrow”), believed to be linked to Israeli intelligence, claimed responsibility and framed the attack as targeting Iran’s sanctions-evasion infrastructure amid rising Iran–Israel tensions rather than for financial gain.

crimeline.aftermath: Nobitex temporarily suspended services.

title: GENIUS Act Signed Into Law
summary: President Trump signed the GENIUS Act into law.

title: CZ-Linked $ASTER Debacle
summary: The CZ/Aster debacle centers on Changpeng Zhao (CZ), the former Binance CEO, heavily promoting and investing in Aster DEX and its token $ASTER in late 2025, driving massive hype, a Binance spot listing, and a price surge to an all-time high around $2.40 in September. However, subsequent issues—including airdrop delays, wash trading allegations leading to a brief DefiLlama delisting, technical glitches, rumored large dumps (which CZ denied), and ongoing monthly token unlocks—triggered sharp crashes, accusations of pump-and-dump manipulation, and heavy retail losses as the token fell over 70% to trade around $0.71 to $0.74 by early January 2026.

title: Cobie's UpOnly Returns After Coinbase Buys the $25m NFT
summary: Coinbase purchased the UpOnly NFT for $25M, triggering the podcasts return.

title: Cobie Sells Echo to Coinbase for ~$375M
summary: Coinbase agreed to acquire Echo in a deal reported at roughly $375M.

title: Upbit Solana Hot Wallet Hack (~$36M)
summary: South Korean exchange Upbit reported a hot wallet compromise where attackers stole around $36M in Solana-based assets.

crimeline.aftermath: Upbit has pledged to fully cover all losses

title: First Chainlink Spot ETF Launches
summary: Grayscales Chainlink product converted/listed as GLNK on NYSE

title: Trust Wallet Extension Compromise
summary: Trust Wallet reported that a malicious/unapproved Chrome extension release (v2.68) was published outside its standard process. Approximately 2,500 wallets were drained.

crimeline.aftermath: Extension rollout halted. Funds are SAFU per CZ

title: Hal Finney Tests Bitcoin
summary: Hal Finney posts the first widely cited Bitcoin tweet, writing "Running bitcoin" as he tests the early software alongside Satoshi Nakamoto.

title: The infamous BTC Sale at $0.30
summary: A viral tweet laments selling 1,700 BTC at $0.30, becoming an early symbol of Bitcoin regret as prices climb.

title: Wikileaks Accepts Bitcoin Donations
summary: Wikileaks begins accepting Bitcoin donations, a milestone that cemented BTC as a censorship-resistant funding rail.

title: Satoshi’s Final Message
summary: Satoshi Nakamoto signs off with "I've moved on to other things," marking the creator's last known public communication.

title: The Casascius Physical Bitcoins Era
summary: Mike Caldwell mints the first Casascius physical Bitcoin coins, blending collectible tokens with real BTC value.

title: The Birth of Dogecoin
summary: Billy Markus and Jackson Palmer launch Dogecoin, turning a meme into one of crypto's largest communities.

title: Cobie Helps Create Maxcoin
summary: Maxcoin launches during the 2014 altcoin wave, marking a very early, and maybe regretable token experiment.

title: I Will Make You Obsolete
summary: Nicolas Dorier responds to BitPay with the iconic "I will make you obsolete" declaration, a rallying cry for user-controlled Bitcoin tools. It ultimately led to BTCPay Server becoming a major open-source, self-hosted Bitcoin payment processor.

title: Wasawasawasa Bitconnectttt!
summary: Carlos Matos delivers the "BitConnectttttt" stage performance that becomes a viral symbol of the 2017 ico boom.

title: Roger Ver Claims Bitcoin Cash is Bitcoin
summary: In August 2017, a long-running dispute over how to scale Bitcoin culminated in a hard fork that created Bitcoin Cash, favoring larger blocks and on-chain transactions over SegWit and Layer-2 solutions. Roger Ver loudly promoted Bitcoin Cash as the “real Bitcoin,” posting viral tweets like “Bitcoin Cash is Bitcoin” and leveraging Bitcoin.com branding to reinforce that claim. The episode sparked years of confusion, branding wars, and tribalism, becoming one of the most infamous ideological splits in crypto history.

links.label: BCH is Bitcoin. Bitcoin Core is not

title: The Birth of Inversebrah
summary: Inversebrah emerges as a foundational CT anon account following @cryptostardust's suspension.

title: The Binance SAFU Origin
summary: In April 2018, Changpeng Zhao (CZ) misspelled “safe” as “SAFU” during a response on Twitter while reassuring users during routine maintenance concerns. The typo went viral on Crypto Twitter, and Binance leaned into it, later formalizing the joke into the Secure Asset Fund for Users (SAFU) in July 2018, an emergency insurance fund seeded with trading fees. The term became legendary after Binance used SAFU funds to fully cover losses from the May 2019 Binance hack, cementing “Funds are SAFU” as crypto lore.

title: Facebook Unveils Short-Lived Libra
summary: Facebook unveils Libra, an ambitious plan for a global digital currency that sparks immediate regulatory attention. Timing is everything.

title: Craig Wright Lies About Being "Satoshi"
summary: Craig Wright repeatedly claims to be Satoshi Nakamoto, igniting ongoing legal and community disputes. in 2024, A UK judge ruled that Craig Wright lied extensively and forged documents on a grand scale while falsely claiming to be Satoshi Nakamoto, the creator of Bitcoin.

title: The PlusToken Ponzi
summary: PlusToken was a massive cryptocurrency Ponzi scheme and wallet platform that started in 2018, mainly attracting investors in China and South Korea by promising high monthly rewards for depositing crypto like BTC and ETH into its app. At its peak, the scam collected **billions of dollars worth of crypto — estimates range from about $2 billion to nearly $3 billion (and possibly more when considering additional movements), making it one of the largest crypto frauds ever. The scheme began to collapse in mid-2019 when investors struggled to withdraw funds, and the operators abruptly emptied billions of dollars of assets and posted messages suggesting they were gone. Subsequent arrests of suspects occurred in June 2019 and later in 2020.

root_cause: Ponzi scheme disguised as crypto wallet and investment platform
Lack of transparency and regulatory oversight
crimeline.aftermath: Operators prosecuted; assets partially seized by authorities

title: $SUSHI Goes After Uni
summary: The SushiSwap vampire attack was one of the most dramatic moments of DeFi Summer 2020, when SushiSwap launched a fork of Uniswap and incentivized users to migrate liquidity away from Uniswap by offering newly minted $SUSHI tokens as rewards. In just days, billions in liquidity had moved. Uniswap answered with the UNI airdrop and LP rewards, while Sushi would run into chef troubles.

title: The Chef and His $SUSHI
summary: SushiSwap’s anonymous founder Chef Nomi withdrew 20,039 ETH and 2.5 million $SUSHI tokens from the developer fund, causing an 80% crash and sparking outrage. Nomi later returns $14m in funds and hands control to Sam Bankman-Fried to stabilize the protocol.

crimeline.aftermath: Chef Nomi returned funds and ceded control to SBF; the incident became defining DeFi governance lore.

title: The UNI Airdrop
summary: Uniswap distributed 400 UNI tokens to wallets that had ever interacted with the protocol before the snapshot date, instantly rewarding users with thousands of dollars each. The airdrop was one of DeFi summer's biggest events. Since then, airdrops have become a key part of crypto.

title: The Birth of (3,3) Lore
summary: OlympusDAO popularized the “(3,3)” meme to describe a gamified incentive structure where all participants are rewarded for staking and cooperating rather than selling. The (3,3) meme became one of the most famous Crypto Twitter in-jokes of the DeFi era, showing up in thousands of replies and bios as a shorthand for protocol loyalty & staking behavior. It summed DeFi yields into a simple “game” outcome that traders could laugh about long after Olympus peaked.

title: The Twitter Help Desk Hack
summary: Twitter suffered a historic breach when attackers social-engineered Twitter employees and gained access to internal help-desk/admin tools, allowing them to take over high-profile accounts including Elon Musk, Barack Obama, Apple, Uber, and others. The compromised accounts posted a Bitcoin scam promising to double any BTC sent, briefly netting the attackers over $100k and sending Crypto Twitter into chaos. Twitter responded by locking many verified accounts from tweeting, underscoring how centralized “trusted access” can become a single point of failure.

title: Saylor Goes All In on Bitcoin
summary: MicroStrategy announced it had purchased $250 million worth of Bitcoin, marking the first major public company to convert treasury reserves into BTC. Led by Michael Saylor, the move legitimized Bitcoin as a corporate reserve asset and triggered a wave of institutional adoption narratives that reshaped crypto markets.

title: You can now buy Tesla with Bitcoin
summary: Tesla disclosed it had bought Bitcoin worth $1.5 billion in early Feb 2021 as part of a corporate investment policy and said it planned to accept BTC as payment, which pushed Bitcoin prices sharply higher on the news.

links.label: You can now buy Tesla with Bitcoin

title: The El Salvador Legal Tender Act
summary: El Salvador adopts Bitcoin as legal tender, with President Bukele repeatedly "buying the dip."

title: The ConstitutionDAO Loses to Ken Griffin
summary: ConstitutionDAO was a decentralized crowdfunding effort that raised over $40 million+ in ETH within just days in November 2021, to bid on a Sotheby’s auction for the historic document. It ultimately lost the auction to Citadel's Ken Griffin, dissolved, and refunded contributors.

title: By My Hand $Luna Will Die
summary: GCR publicly proposed a $10 million bet to Do Kwon (Terraform Labs’ co-founder) that the price of $LUNA would be lower a year later than it was then, effectively shorting the Terra ecosystem before its catastrophic collapse.

title: Your Size Is Not Size
summary: Do Kwon's "your size is not size" remark goes viral amid debate over LUNA's sustainability.

title: Steady Lads
summary: Do Kwon urges calm with "steady lads" as UST begins to unravel.

title: The GCR 72-Cent Hedge
summary: GCR buys cheap insurance to hedge a large LUNA short, later cited as a legendary trade.

title: The 3Arrows Capital Files Bankruptcy
summary: As markets collapsed, Three Arrows Capital abruptly stopped responding to lenders, counterparties, and the public, triggering liquidation cascades across the industry. The silence became infamous when founders Su Zhu and Kyle Davies went quiet while exposure rumors spread. Days later, 3AC was ordered into liquidation.

title: 1) What
summary: As FTX collapsed into bankruptcy, Sam Bankman-Fried posted a cryptic one-word tweet — “1)What” — beginning a slow thread that appeared to spell out “What happened.” It became one of the most enraging and infamous moments of the FTX implosion.

title: CZ Heads For The Exit First
summary: CZ announces Binance will liquidate rought $2.1 billion in FTT holdings, triggering a rapid loss of confidence and the inevitable FTX implosion.

title: I Fked Up
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried posts "I fked up" as the FTX collapse unfolds.

title: Martin Shkreli tells Do Kwon Jail Is Not That Bad
summary: Martin Shkreli appears on UpOnly and tells Do Kwon jail isn't that bad.

title: Inscriptions are finally ready for Bitcoin mainnet
summary: This tweet marked the point when the Ordinals protocol was enabled on Bitcoin mainnet, allowing users to inscribe arbitrary data (like art or text) onto individual satoshis — effectively bringing Bitcoin-native NFTs onchain.

title: The $1.3 Million Frosties Arrest
summary: U.S. federal authorities arrested and charged two men — Ethan Vinh Nguyen and Andre Marcus Llacuna — for their roles in an alleged NFT fraud and money-laundering scheme involving the Frosties collection.

title: The Squid Game Token Crash
summary: The Squid Game token spikes to $2,800 before plummetting violently as the developers vanished in a rug pull, taking with them an estimated $3 million in investor funds. The rug pull incident was recorded during a livestream from stream SimonZ.

title: The Gary Gensler "I Will Resign" Tweet
summary: Gary Gensler announced that he would step down as Chair of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission effective January 20, 2025, coinciding with the inauguration of the new presidential administration.

title: The James Wynn Implosion
summary: At his peak in 2025, onchain data showed Wynn’s trading account reached about $87 million in profit, much of it from early memecoin plays like PEPE and leveraged BTC longs. By May 2025, Wynn lost about $100 million in a single week of leveraged BTC trades, erasing nearly all his Hyperliquid profits. He continued to get wiped out. “I flipped $3M into $100M and somehow ended up negative $13M. I lost control.” — James Wynn

title: Gainzy `Fat Fingers`His Token
summary: Alleged CEO Killer and Pump Fun streamer, Gainzy, accidentally sold 73.4% of the supply of his own creator token $GNZYSTRM in one transaction. A move he claims was just a “fat-finger misclick” while fiddling with his phone. The massive sell caused the token’s market cap to crash about 99% in seconds, dropping from roughly $4.6 M to ~$12k.

title: Peanut the Squirrel (PNUT)
summary: $PNUT was created in 2024 as a meme coin inspired by the viral story of Peanut the Squirrel, which sparked widespread online outrage after the animal was seized and euthanized by authorities.

title: The Cobie Insider Trading Ident
summary: Cobie highlighted onchain wallet activity that appeared to front-run token listings on Coinbase, suggesting possible insider trading. The investigation led to criminal and civil charges against a COinbase product manager and his brother and friend.

title: The Snoop Dogg $12M Telegram Drop
summary: Snoop Dogg launched a limited NFT-style digital collectible drop directly through Telegram, which reportedly sold out in minutes and generated roughly $12 million. The event went viral because it bypassed traditional NFT marketplaces

title: See you in Hell
summary: Cobie burns $17M `worth` of gifted Pump.fun token, calling out memecoin chaos.

title: Zcash Core Developers Resign
summary: Multiple Zcash core developers resigned in early 2026, citing governance and strategic disagreements.

title: Vitalik Takes a Photo
summary: A candid photo of Ethereum co-founder Vitalik Buterin is circulated on Twitter.

title: Charles Hoskinson Tweets From The Ranch
summary: "You're telling the CEO of IOHK, founder of Cardano and Ethereum to use the support email? Just wanted to ask about the chrome delisting." This came after he reached out to MetaMask support via Twitter.

title: Erik Voorhees Debates SBF and It Goes Bad
summary: Just days before FTX’s collapse, Erik Voorhees debated Sam Bankman-Fried on Bankless, with the discussion ironically highlighting criticisms over custody, trust, and centralized finance.

title: Randi Zuckerberg Gifts Us a Crypto Song
summary: Randi sings and dances in a parody music video about crypto, which was shared widely online and truly highlights the madness of 2021/2022.

title: SBF: 'I Will Buy All You Have at $3'
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried tweeted an aggressive threat during a market dispute, promising to buy all supply at $3 before telling the critic to 'fuck off.'

title: Ledger Dances on UpOnly
summary: Ledgerstatus shows us his dance moves on the UpOnly podcast. The FTX shirt was truly the cherry-on-top. Pure cinema.

title: Algod Becomes Bahaman to Withdraw FTX Funds
summary: Algod (or AlgodTrading) reportedly exploited a loophole where Bahamian-registered FTX accounts could still withdraw funds due to pressure from Bahamian regulators to protect local users, while most international accounts were frozen.

title: A Highly Profitable Trading Strategy
summary: Avi Eisenberg exploited Mango Markets, later stating 'What are you gonna do, arrest me?'— a quote that became infamous after he was actually arrested.

crimeline.aftermath: Avi arrested and prosecuted.

title: 'All Funds Are Safe'
summary: Days before Celsius froze withdrawals, CEO Alex Mashinsky publicly claimed all funds were safe, in one of the most infamous statements of the 2022 collapse.

title: John McAfee Says He Will Eat His Own D*ck
summary: John McAfee famously promised to eat his own body part if Bitcoin didn’t reach $500k in 3 years. An absurd and legendary bet. RIP.

title: Jihan Wu and the Bitmain Power Era
summary: Jihan Wu, co-founder of Bitmain, became one of the most influential and controversial figures for his role in the Bitcoin Cash vs BTC era. Wu backed BCH to address BTC's transaction limits, contrasting with BTC's SegWit soft fork; this stance fueled market volatility, with BCH briefly surpassing $2,000 in December 2017. Wu and Bitmain were defendants in a U.S. antitrust case alleging they conspired with others (Roger Ver, Kraken, etc.) to manipulate the Bitcoin Cash market during the BCH fork drama. A federal judge dismissed all claims; Bitmain and Wu walked.

title: Cobie Posts His Buy Wall
summary: During a violent market selloff, Cobie publicly posted his massive buy wall, turning the phrase into a legendary Crypto Twitter moment symbolizing conviction and capital.

title: Crypto: The Game S2
summary: S2: Anon Island brought new heights for CTG. 800 players minted in 13 minutes for a 72 ETH pot (~$250k), divided into tribes for 10 days of arcade challenges, puzzles, and cutthroat votes. It sold out faster than S1, drawing celebs, VCs, and degens.

title: Crypto: The Game S3
summary: CTG: Ressurection Island was played on Unichain, after the Uniswap acquisition. Season Three featured 716 contestants all competing for 71.6 ETH.

title: Crypto: The Game Begins
summary: Crypto: The Game launches the first season of their onchain competition. Players mint an entry NFT for .1 ETH, with accrued fees going directly into the communal prize pool. Season 1 (Jan/Feb 2024): 410 players → ~$100k+ pot won by a Japan-based player, who wrote poems for other players.

title: Tornado Cash Sanctions Begin
summary: n August 2022, authorities escalated enforcement against Tornado Cash after U.S. sanctions, leading to the arrest of developer Alexey Pertsev in the Netherlands. The crackdown intensified in 2023 when U.S. prosecutors charged Roman Storm. The original OFAC sanctions on Tornado Cash were challenged and partially overturned by a U.S. appeals court in late 2024 (ruling that autonomous protocols can't be sanctioned as 'property'). Sanctions were lifted in March 2025, but the criminal case against Storm continues.

title: BitBoy Livestreams His Arrest
summary: Crypto influencer BitBoy was arrested outside a former employee's home. It was a highly publicized meltdown that included a weapon, his mistress, and a Youtube livestream.

title: BitBoy vs Ansem Match
summary: BitBoy and Ansem clash publicly in the ring on December 6th, 2024.

title: Gainzy Goes Gambling
summary: Gainzy posts massive high-stakes bets, often $100k–$300k+ per bet, and helped drive huge attention to Rollbit. Concerns arose that Rollbit was secretly funding these high stakes bets. ZachXBT and community members called him out. Gainzy eventually announced a sponsorship with Stake.com.

title: BitBoy Finds His Inner Alex Jones
summary: BitBoy launched a chaotic rant involving RSA, after Ryan Sean Adams tweets Bitboy

title: Vitalik: Ethereum on Steroids
summary: A meme referencing Vitalik describing Ethereum as being 'on steroids' circulated widely, becoming shorthand for aggressive scaling narratives.

title: I don't have time to try to convince you, sorry
summary: Satoshi Nakamoto’s quote: 'If you don’t believe me or don’t get it, I don’t have time to try to convince you'. One of the most cited philosophical statements in Bitcoin culture.

title: Kevin NFT Rug Pull Turns To Comedy
summary: The Pixelmon project hyped a AAA game, minted out at ~3 ETH each, pulled in massive funds totaling around $70m... then revealed absolute dogwater art, with Kevin becoming the face of disappointment. ZachXBT investigated and discovered that instead of investing in development, the team spent 400 ETH purchasing blue-chip NFTs (Bored Apes, Azukis) for themselves. The Kevin NFT art was so poorly executed that it crossed from scam into comedy, becoming a long-running joke on CT.

crimeline.aftermath: Became a meme rather than a legal case.

title: Nikita Says Crypto Twitter Is "Dying From Suicide"
summary: Nikita Bier sparked backlash on Crypto Twitter after claiming that CT is "dying from suicide," arguing that the community is harming itself through low-quality engagement farming, rather than being suppressed solely by platform algorithms. The comments quickly became a flashpoint in ongoing debates about CT's decline on Twitter, engagement farming, and the impact of their recent algorithm changes.

title: Genesis Creditor Heist
summary: On August 19, 2024, three attackers—Malone Lam (Greavys), Veer Chetal (Wiz), and Jeandiel Serrano (Box)—orchestrated one of the largest single-victim crypto thefts in history, stealing 4,064 BTC ($243M) from a Genesis creditor. Using sophisticated social engineering, they impersonated Google and Gemini support to reset the victim's 2FA and drain the wallet. ZachXBT's investigation uncovered a leaked celebration video showing attackers' real-time reactions, Instagram posts of luxury spending including pink car gifts, and device fingerprints linking them to Mark Cuban's June 2024 compromise. FBI raids in Miami and LA on September 18, 2024 led to multiple arrests. A fourth suspect, British national Danish Zulfiqar, was reportedly arrested in Dubai in December 2024 with $18.5M seized. Funds were rapidly laundered across 15+ exchanges.

crimeline.aftermath: FBI raids resulted in multiple arrests including Malone Lam and Jeandiel Serrano. Fourth suspect Danish Zulfiqar arrested in Dubai with $18.5M seized. $9M frozen across exchanges, $500K returned to victim.

title: Harmony Bridge Hack
summary: Harmony disclosed a ~$100M theft from its Horizon bridge, after attackers drained bridge-held assets and began laundering proceeds across Ethereum. U.S. authorities later attributed the hack to North Korea’s Lazarus Group (APT38). ZachXBT tracked subsequent laundering flows onchain, including large movements of Harmony-hack ETH routed through privacy tooling (e.g., Railgun) during the 2023 laundering phase.

crimeline.aftermath: FBI attributed attacks to North Korea's Lazarus Group and APT38. Funds laundered through privacy protocols. Minimal recovery despite exchange freezes.

title: Coinbase Social Engineering Scam Ring
summary: A sophisticated, organized phishing operation impersonated Coinbase customer support to steal over $65M from users. The scammers created professional fake support panels, spoofed official communication channels (email, SMS, social media), and used advanced social engineering to convince victims to share recovery phrases and authentication credentials. The operation involved multiple team members playing different roles. ZachXBT identified and publicly named individual threat actors, traced complex fund flows across multiple blockchains, and documented the complete infrastructure. Law enforcement took partial action against the ring, though the decentralized nature made complete takedown challenging.

crimeline.aftermath: ZachXBT identified and named multiple threat actors. Law enforcement took partial action against organized groups.

title: Machi Big Brother x ZachXBT Lawsuit
summary: In June 2022, ZachXBT published a comprehensive investigation alleging Jeffrey Huang ('Machi Big Brother'), misappropriated over $37M from various projects and community funds across 21+ connected wallets. The investigation detailed suspicious fund movements, treasury misuse, and questionable transactions. In response, Huang filed a defamation lawsuit in June 2023 attempting to silence the investigation. The crypto community rallied behind ZachXBT, raising over $1 million for legal defense within days. Huang eventually withdrew the lawsuit after ZachXBT made minor edits to the original report.

title: Bored Ape Yacht Club Phishing Ring
summary: Between December 2021 and early 2022, a coordinated French phishing ring targeted high-value BAYC and MAYC NFT holders, stealing $2.5M+. Scammers posed as verified Discord members and created fake websites promising to 'animate' victims' Bored Ape NFTs. When victims connected wallets and approved transactions, their NFTs were immediately stolen and sold on OpenSea. The first victim, 'Dilly Dilly,' lost BAYC #237 (47 ETH/$178K) on December 13, 2021. Despite using Tornado Cash, the scammers made mistakes in withdrawal patterns. ZachXBT's August 2022 'Scammers in Paris' investigation used blockchain analysis and social media forensics to identify perpetrators Mathys and Camille.

crimeline.aftermath: ZachXBT's 'Scammers in Paris' investigation matched Telegram profile pictures to Twitter/Instagram accounts, identifying Mathys and Camille. French authorities arrested five individuals in October 2022. ZachXBT's research officially credited in court documents as initiating investigation. Assets partially recovered.

title: HZ (Chase Senecal) NFT Phishing Scams
summary: Chase Senecal, operating under aliases 'HZ' and 'Horror,' ran a targeted NFT phishing operation stealing over $260K from high-value NFT collectors using sophisticated wallet approval phishing techniques. Victims were tricked into signing malicious transactions that granted Senecal access to their wallets. ZachXBT's investigation meticulously tracked stolen NFTs and connected multiple wallets to Senecal's identity through social media cross-referencing and on-chain analysis. The investigation directly led to FBI involvement and landmark seizures.

crimeline.aftermath: FBI confiscated all $260K in crypto assets, NFTs, watches, jewelry, and luxury goods. Chase Senecal arrested. First major FBI seizure directly from ZachXBT investigation. Established blockchain forensics as viable evidence for law enforcement. Demonstrated pseudonymous activity can be traced to real identities.
